questions.text: A biker met with an accident and sustained a maxillofacial injury. Which of the following is the first step in the primary care of this patient?
questions.solution:
The first step in primary care of a patient with a maxillofacial injury is securing an adequate airway.

Evaluation of facial fractures:

  • A & B – Airway & Breathing: the first objective is to ensure an adequate airway by intubation or tracheostomy.
  • C – Circulation: control of haemorrhage by pressure or ligation of bleeding vessels.
  • Rule out head and spinal injuries.
  • Neurological evaluation.
  • Examine for injuries in other parts of the body.
  • Care of the wound.
  • Documentation of the injuries for medico-legal purposes.
  • Examination of the facial skeleton – mandible, maxilla, zygomatic and orbital fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following facial bones is most commonly fractured?
questions.solution: The most commonly fractured bone of the face is the nasal bone because of the projection of the nose on the face.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with a nasal bleed after sustaining a blow to the nose in a fistfight. On evaluation, a nasal septal fracture similar to the one in the image below was identified. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of nasal bleed following trauma and the image showing a horizontal fracture line is suggestive of Jarjaway fracture.

It is a fracture of the nasal septum that results from direct blows from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally from just above the anterior nasal spine to just above the junction of septal cartilage with vomer. 

Option C: Chevallet fracture results from blows from below. The fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose.

Option D: Tripod fracture is another name for zygoma fracture.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.solution:
The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once the edema has subsided.

The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, the deformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After 3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinical assessment.

After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony and fibrous union would have started.

questions.text: As an ENT resident, you are assisting in the reduction of a nasal bone fracture. Which of the following instruments would you use?
questions.solution:
Walsham forceps (Image 2) is used to reduce a nasal bone fracture.

Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture.

 

Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy.

 

Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis.

 

Option D: Citelli’s forceps is used for bone punch.

questions.text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture.

Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence. 
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. 
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. 
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. 
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. 
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.text: You are an ENT resident evaluating a patient with a fracture of the zygoma. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma.

It has the following clinical features:

  • Flattening of malar prominence.
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
  • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve.
  • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.
  • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament.
  • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.
  • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.text: A patient with a tripod fracture is having decreased sensation over the cheek. Which of the following nerve injuries can result in this?
questions.solution: Infraorbital nerve injury results in decreased sensation over the cheek in tripod(zygomatic) fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following is called blow-out fractures?

choices.text: Fracture of lateral wall of orbit
Fracture of medial wall of orbit

questions.solution:
Fracture of the floor of the orbit is called blow-out fracture.

It occurs when a large blunt object strikes the globe.

questions.text: A teenage boy suffered trauma to his left eye while playing cricket. He is rushed to the ER in severe pain. His X-ray appears as below. What is the characteristic sign noted?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the tear-drop sign. It is seen in orbital floor or blow-out fractures when the orbital contents herniate into the maxillary antrum.

Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen.

Options C and D: Antral and Holman Miller signs are the same. It is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

questions.text: A 19-year-old college student presented with complaints of seeing double after sustaining a blow to his face in a scuffle with his seniors. On examination, there is a step deformity and periorbital emphysema. Entrapment of which of the following muscles is likely to be responsible for his double vision?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with diplopia, periorbital emphysema, and a step deformity can be seen in both orbital floor fracture as well as tripod fracture. In both conditions diplopia is due to:

  • Entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles
  • Displacement of the eyeball.

The common features seen in both orbital floor fracture and tripod fracture are:

  • Periorbital emphysema
  • Step deformity of infraorbital margin
  • Diplopia
  • Enophthalmos.

questions.text: In which of the following fractures Le-Fort classification is used?
questions.solution:
Le-Fort classification is used in the fracture of the maxilla.

The 3 types are:

  • Le Fort I (transverse fracture)
  • Le Fort II (pyramidal fracture)
  • Le Fort III (craniofacial disjunction).

Related Pearl: Le-Fort's classification of Maxillary Fracture

Le-Fort I is a transverse fracture of the maxilla
  • Fracture line passes through the lower part of nasal septum, maxillary antra and the pterygoid plates
  • It separates palate from the rest of the face leading to floating teeth or palate
  • Also called Guerin’s fracture. 
Le-Fort II is a pyramidal fracture
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, lacrimal bone, floor of the orbit, upper part of the maxillary sinus and pterygoid plates
  • X-ray or CT appears like hanging maxilla
  • It is associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
Le-Fort III is craniofacial dysjunction i.e., facial skeleton completely disconnected from its cranial attachment
  • Fracture line passes through the root of the nose, ethmo-frontal junction, superior orbital fissure, lateral wall of the orbit, fronto-zygomatic and temporo-zygomatic sutures and the upper part of pterygoid plates
  • It is also associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: Which of the following bones is not involved in Le-Fort fractures?
questions.solution:
The mandible is not involved in Le-Fort’s fractures.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common site for fracture of the mandible in children?
questions.solution:
The most common site of fracture of the mandible in children is the condyle. It is because the condylar head is connected to the vertical ramus of the bone by a thin neck which gives away easily to an impact.

Mandibular fractures:

Children:

  • Due to falls and sports injuries.
  • Most common site - condyle.

Adults > 50 years:

  • Most commonly due to falls.
  • Most common site - body (the molar area is the weakest area in an edentulous mandible).

Young Adults:

  • Due to falls, assaults, and accidents.
  • The site of fracture depends on the nature of impact and the direction of force applied.

questions.text: A 23-year-old college student presented with jaw pain and trismus after falling from a bike. A diagnosis of mandibular fracture was made. Which of the following classification is used for this?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Following trauma, a patient presented with clear watery nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back. Fractures of which of the following bones is the most likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause for this.

Causes of CSF rhinorrhea:

  • Trauma (accidental or surgical) - most of the cases follow trauma. Surgical trauma includes endoscopic sinus surgery, trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, nasal polypectomy, or skull base surgery.
  • Inflammations - mucoceles of sinuses, sinonasal polyposis, the fungal infection of sinuses and osteomyelitis, can all erode the bone and dura.
  • Neoplasms - tumours, both benign and malignant, invading the skull base.
  • Congenital lesions - meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas can have associated skull base defects.
  • Idiopathic - where the cause is unknown and the patient has a spontaneous leak.

questions.text: Which of the following fractures is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.solution:
Le-Fort I fracture is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Whereas, fractures like Le-Fort II, III and naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture are associated with CSF rhinorrhea.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman, who had undergone a polypectomy complains of watery nasal discharge on bending forward. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery.

Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea:
1. The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance.
2. It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D)
3. It does not stiffen a handkerchief.
4. It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in drops only on bending the head forward/straining.  
5. The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when a clear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/paper towel.
6. Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluid accumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of β 2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen.

β 2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus.

Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph.

Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about CSF rhinorrhea?

choices.text: Ethmoid is the most common site of leak
Intrathecal fluorescein study can be used to detect site of leak

questions.solution:
Double ring sign is present in a case of CSF rhinorrhea.

Double ring sign or Halo sign or Target sign - when CSF mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

Option A: Fracture cribriform plate of ethmoid is the most common cause.

Option B: CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose.

Option C: Intrathecal fluorescein study is used to detect the site of leak of CSF.

questions.text: What is the preferred line of management in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea who is otherwise stable?
questions.solution:
Patients with CSF rhinorrhea who are stable, are managed conservatively. 

The conservative measures are:

  • Bed rest
  • Elevation of the head end
  • Stool softeners
  • Avoidance of nose-blowing, sneezing, and straining.

Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis and acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation. Surgery is done if the conservative management fails.
